Stories.title: CosmicLitch
pages: As prophecy foretold, The Frost Singer did emerge from the desolate north, it rose to the highest peak of Velmili, annihilating anything that tried to stop it, and it's howl doomed our world. Pandemonium ensued. The Brethren of Frostsong, a growing deathcult of apocalyptical zealots, felt justified in their scriptures prophecy, and began their final chapter, The Holy Struggle. Millions were slaughtered by bloodthirsty psychopaths, following the words of a long-dead tyrant who promised his followers the world, once it had been cleansed of sinners by the Frostsong. I refused to allow them even a Pyrrhic victory, and thus, I would have to break all dogmas of this world, and have my seance with Om. Those few who could still perform cosmic magick were the most valued targets so I hid, I hid while millions died; I did the covenant with the Veil, the largest sin Velmili. I disrobed and spoke the spell, unholy words that were punishable by death in the times where our world was not on the brink of collapse:

"Hear me now, Cosmos, above 
 For a mortal yearns to see, 
 The hidden truths, beyond my scope, 
 Cosmos: speak to me. 
 
 My mind was plunged into darkness. Then I witnessed the birth of stars, billions of years flowing past in mere minutes. I saw the end of the universe, and then I met Om: an infinitely sprawling net of celestial light. It's net, or grid, contained shining orbs at every intersection of the light beams, reflecting the infinity of every other orb. 
 
 "Hello reflection. It has been long since I have been visited, by your standards, that is. What do you ask of Om?"

"Do not let my people die." 
 "Well, everyone dies, everything dies, dear reflection." 
 "Then are we to be doomed to be wiped from history, entombed under kilometers of ice on a dead world,  our culture and society erased without a trace?" 
 "There is nothing I can do to stop them dying." 
 "Then what can you do, oh "mighty" Om, would infinite paradise suffice? 
 I awoke, my body had been transformed into an alien shape that did not match my own. Powers untold flowed through me. I was now the Cosmic Litch, and I could hear Om speaking to me, a soothing voice from within: 
 "Do you accept the burdens I have bestowed upon you, dear reflection?" 
 "Yes, I do. Anything will be worth for the Simusacrum. Thank you, dear reflection." 
 "Very well. I wish you luck in your endeavors. I will await you at the end of time."

What us Velmili had called Cosmic Magick was but a fraction of the celestial Powers contained in my new form. I manifested the Temple of Remembrance: fusing the various elements in the air, snow and rock, until the Cosmic Temple had been formed in its entirety. Not just an impenetrable exterior, but the infrastructure to maintain our homeostasis. With the temple completed, I went to the lowest chamber, and conjured the Simusacrum, a gyrating orb of light that would be the resting place of my sullen people. Everything had been completed, so I raised a pillar of light from the Temple of Remembrance, a beacon of hope for my dying people. Soon, they came, in huddled caravans. Many died on the way, for the frost had been getting worse by each passing day. Those who came to be saved in the Simusacrum could touch the orb, and their conscious mind transported within it.

Their former flesh vessels, dissolved to and reforged into Biosteel, which would be used to create the Clockwork Automatons, future bodies for those who wish to return to this physical realm. I made them bodies that could be rebuilt, recycled, that and could survive even the frost death of our world. I doubt that anyone will ever enter one, because I have given them the Simusacrum, and it was my duty to protect it. The caravans slowed, and the numbers of arrivals were dwindling. Survivors of the Brethren of Frostsong's carnage told me of countless joining their ranks, in desperate attempts to avoid their doom. They had no mercy, and those who were not Bretheren, had to be destroyed, for if not, the world will never be reborn for them. I sealed the temple, and prepared for my last stand against the Zealots, just myself and the two Mandoro Guardians. Despite the Frost having thinned their horde, there numbers were immense, a final stand against any heretics.

I killed countless to defend the temple, and I hope I did the right thing. The frost will take the rest soon enough, for they retreated into the growing blizzards. I am dying now, the threat is stopped, but the Temple of Remembrance has not been breached, and the Simusacrum will protect my people. These are my last thoughts entrusted to the Clockwork Queen, the eternal custodian of my people. I am in pain, their scythes having shredded my form. I'm not afraid. I made a choice, and did what I set out to accomplish. I just hope that I can be forgiven for what I had to..." His life ended in that moment, his corpse preserved in honor by myself. I will sleep now. Perhaps one day new life will find us. And they will know that once there were the Velmili, and on the eve of their doom, the Cosmic Litch gave himself to save our memory from oblivion. It is the year 2177 of Velmili Standard Time. Goodnight dear reflections.

Stories.title: FallborneDragon
pages: The most merciful thing in the world, I think, is the inability of the human mind to correlate all its contents. We live on a placid island of ignorance in the midst of black seas of infinity, and it was not meant that we should voyage far. The sciences, each straining in its own direction, have hitherto harmed us little; but some day the piecing together of dissociated knowledge will open up such terrifying vistas of reality, and of our frightful position therein, that we shall either go mad from the revelation or flee from the deadly light into the peace and safety of a new dark age.

Cthulhu still lives, too, I suppose, again in that chasm of stone which has shielded him since the sun was young. His accursed city is sunken once more, for the Vigilant sailed over the spot after the April storm; but his ministers on earth still bellow and prance and slay around idol-capped monoliths in lonely places. He must have been trapped by the sinking whilst within his black abyss, or else the world would by now be screaming with fright and frenzy. Who knows the end? What has risen may sink, and what has sunk may rise. Loathsomeness waits and dreams in the deep, and decay spreads over the tottering cities of men. A time will come—but I must not and cannot think! Let me pray that, if I do not survive this manuscript, my executors may put caution before audacity and see that it meets no other eye.
